ONE Hm~DRED TWENTY-NINTH SPECIAL MEETING of
EXECUTIVE DIRECTORS
Board Room International Bank Building Washington, D. C. Tuesday, May 28, 1957
The meeting was convened at 10:05 o'clock a.m., Mr. Eugene Black, Fresident J presiding.  2

Now I would like to go over to a pl~asant subject and tell you a little bit about the trip I have just had. I just
got back day before yesterday, and I might just tell you some
of the things I did in each one of these countries, which will give you an idea of what happened.
I went to Japan, and this is my first visit there. I
was accompanied by Mr. Rosen, the Director of the new Far
Eastern Division, and Mr. Quandt, to whom we have assigned
Japan. Before I got there, Mr. DeWilde and Mr. Tolley had
spent six weeks making an up-to-date economic study of the country, which was presented to me by the time that I got
there. We were very fortunate in ha ving Mr. \'latanabe there
at the same time. He was very helpful in our discussions with  25 the government, and he was also very helpful in translat:tng for me about twelve speeches that I had to make. I think I might give you my daily schedule.
We arrived there around the middle of the day, and I
don't th.ink I ha ve ever seen as many photographers hit me at one place as I did when I arrived in Tokyo. The Japanese are
very efficient in making cameras, and an awful lot of them were in the hands of photographers there. Mr. Adlai
stevenson when he visited Japan said he didn't think Japan should be called a democracy. He thought it ought to be
called a "photocracy." That was what I ran into. I had a press conference right at the airport. It was very interestin â€¢
I then called on the Prime Minister, who as you know is now taking a trip allover Southeast Asia and plans to come to Washington next month. Then later on the Prime Minister gave a cocktail party in my honor, and that night the Minister
of Finance ~ve a dinner. The next day I called on the Minister of Finance, then later on the Governor of the Bank of
Japan. Then in the afternoon I called on the Minister of International Trade. And I won't mention the luncheons and dinners that took place every day, except to say they were very pleasant and wonderful food, and the Japanese people are justly famous for their marvelous hospitality. The second day I was there, just after I called on
the Governor of the Bank of Japan, about one hour after I called on him, they raised the bank rate. This was the second
time that they had raised the bank rate, and the next day the
stock market took a nosedive, but fortunately I wasn't accused of having any hand in that. It just happened after
about an hour after I called on the Governor of the Bank of
Japan. The following day I had an interest ing meeting with
the representatives of the banks of Tokyo, and then I called
on the Governor of the Japanese Development Bank. As you
know, that is the bank that we have channeled our loans in
Japan through. The following day there was a conference with the
leading business people in Tokyo, and then we left for
Kyoto and did a little sightseeing there in the surrounding
country for a couple of days. Then we had a conference with
the business leaders in the district and went to see the
Mitsubishi shipyard at Kobe, which was quite an interesting sight, because as you know the shipyards in Japan are loaded
up for three or four years of business. The following day I had the pleasure of meeting the
Emperor and the Empress, and then in the afternoon I visited the factory of the Kalisaki Steel Corporation, which is one
of the pro jects that we ha ve handled in Japan., The next day I had my final meeting with the Minister
of Finance and another press conference, and a meeting in the  27 afternoon with the Minister of Construction, and another meeting with all the foreign bankers who have offices there. The following day I had a meeting with the heads of the largest security company. Then we went to see the Tokyo stock exchange and went to see the International Trade Fair and called on the Governor of the Bank of Japan and a few other people and then left Japan. It was a verY interesting trip. We have made loans totaling $77 million in Japan, and we expect to bring to the Board shortly another loan for an irrigation project of about $10 million. We were approached by the Japanese Government as to the possibility of the Bank extending more loans to Japan or increasing the amount that we had in mind when we first started dOing business there. I informed the Government that we would be willing to recommend additional loans over and above the limit that we had originally set, and we expect to have a project submitted to us covering the bottlenecks in Japan, which were transportation, power, and industrial expansion of particularly steel. They have done a verY good job in that countrY. There has been a little slowdown lately, or rather a reduction in the reserves of about $250 million since the first of the year. The investments have been going pretty fast, and that was the principal reason for the second increase in the bank rate. I was impressed by the fact that  28 most people I talked to in Japan were very keen that the Bank
not only lend money to Japan but that the Bank also increase its activity in Asia. I ran into that everywhere that I went.
They thought it was very important, and they would like to see the Bank be even more active in that area of the world. It
was suggested to us that the Bank might open up a regional office, and that we might open up this regional office in
Japan. I discouraged that, saying that we didn.t like to have regional offices where we didn.t think it would make any
difference. It certainly wouldn't increase the amount of the loans that we made if we had a regional office. But this was part of the picture of their very keen interest in that part of the world in getting a substantial share of the Bankts loans. I was very favorably impressed with the progress in the
country, with the skill and the energy and the resourcefulness. When I say "energy, n that means the hard work, and the
resourcefulness and the managerial ability of the Japanese people. Of course they have problems, as everybody else has,
but you can.t help but be impressed with the job that they have done and are doing today. I was also greatly impressed with the literacy. It is about 99 percent there. It was a very profitable trip.
